articles.headline: Some Companies Shift Health Costs to Better-Paid
articles.snippet: As costs rise, employers are shifting the burden of health care contributions to workers in top salary brackets.
articles.abstract: As costs rise, employers are shifting the burden of health care contributions to workers in top salary brackets.
articles.lead_paragraph: With health care costs climbing even higher during this enrollment season, more employers are adopting a tiered system to pass on the bulk of those costs to their employees by assigning bigger contributions to workers in top salary brackets and offering some relief to workers who make less money.

articles.headline: In Curt Exchange, U.S. Faults Israel on Housing
articles.snippet: The office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu rejected criticism of Israel’s plans from President Obama and others.
articles.abstract: The office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu rejected criticism of Israel’s plans from President Obama and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s criticism of new Israeli housing plans for East Jerusalem, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s even sharper retort, have thrown the Middle East peace talks into jeopardy, with the dispute over Jewish settlements looming as a seemingly insuperable hurdle.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: In These Lean Days, Even Stores Shrink
articles.snippet: Some retailers are cutting the size of stores and inventory to limit costs and provide a focused shopping experience.
articles.abstract: Some retailers are cutting the size of stores and inventory to limit costs and provide a focused shopping experience.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif.  A temporary wall slices the Anchor Blue store here in half. On one side are abandoned dressing rooms, a few mannequins and no customers. On the other are racks jammed with clothing and accessories  and more customers than ever coming into the store.

articles.headline: Challenges Await U.S. at Group of 20 Meeting
articles.snippet: With China leading the critics of American economic policy, officials acknowledge that President Obama is going to have a difficult time winning any kind of consensus strategy.
articles.abstract: With China leading the critics of American economic policy, officials acknowledge that President Obama is going to have a difficult time winning any kind of consensus strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Anyone wondering what President Obama will face when he arrives in South Korea on Wednesday for a global financial summit meeting need look no further than an announcement by China’s leading state-endorsed rating agency, which downgraded the United States’ credit rating on Tuesday  and provocatively questioned American leadership of the global economy.

articles.headline: A 24-Karat Safety Net for Investors
articles.snippet: Investors worry that a Fed move to add $600 billion to the banking system may undermine paper currencies.
articles.abstract: Investors worry that a Fed move to add $600 billion to the banking system may undermine paper currencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Think of it as the Tea Party of investments.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Stage Set for Showdown on Online Privacy
articles.snippet: Two federal agencies are preparing reports on online privacy standards, and the findings could be at odds.
articles.abstract: Two federal agencies are preparing reports on online privacy standards, and the findings could be at odds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After “do not call” lists became popular, more than 90 percent of people who signed up reported fewer annoying telemarketing calls. Now, privacy advocates are pushing for a similar “do not track” feature that would let Internet users tell Web sites to stop surreptitiously tracking their online habits and collecting clues about age, salary, health, location and leisure activities.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: DealBook: A Female Wall St. Financial Chief Avoids Pitfalls That Stymied Others
articles.snippet: Ruth Porat is trying to excel not only during difficult times for Morgan Stanley, but also in the face of a terrible track record for top women on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Ruth Porat is trying to excel not only during difficult times for Morgan Stanley, but also in the face of a terrible track record for top women on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ruth M. Porat has a knack for escaping unscathed from tough situations.

articles.headline: The Enduring Myth of Gold’s Record High
articles.snippet: Despite many news reports that gold has reached a “record high,” it’s not true, at least not in any meaningful sense
articles.abstract: Despite many news reports that gold has reached a “record high,” it’s not true, at least not in any meaningful sense

articles.headline: Tentative Deal in Iraq Keeps Maliki in Power
articles.snippet: Iraq’s leaders reached a tentative agreement to end an eight-month political impasse and return Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to power.
articles.abstract: Iraq’s leaders reached a tentative agreement to end an eight-month political impasse and return Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to power.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s leaders reached a tentative agreement late Wednesday night to create a unity government embracing the country’s major ethnic and religious factions, ending an eight-month political impasse and returning Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to power for a second term as prime minister.
articles.byline: By John Leland and Steven Lee Myers
